questions.question: What is the mean of a dataset?
options: The average of all values
The middle value when data is ordered
The most frequent value
The difference between highest and lowest values
questions.explanation: The mean is the arithmetic average of all values in a dataset, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the number of values.

questions.question: What is standard deviation?
options: A measure of how spread out the values are from the mean
The difference between the highest and lowest values
The middle value of a dataset
The most common value in a dataset
questions.explanation: Standard deviation measures how spread out the values are from the mean, indicating the amount of variation in the dataset.

questions.question: What is a normal distribution?
options: A bell-shaped distribution where data is symmetric around the mean
A distribution where all values are equal
A distribution with two peaks
A distribution with no pattern
questions.explanation: A normal distribution is a bell-shaped curve where data is symmetric around the mean, with most values falling near the mean and fewer values at the extremes.

questions.question: What is correlation?
options: A measure of the relationship between two variables
The difference between two means
The sum of squared differences
The ratio of two standard deviations
questions.explanation: Correlation measures the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables, ranging from -1 to +1.

questions.question: What is a p-value?
options: The probability of obtaining results as extreme as the observed results
The percentage of data points in a sample
The mean of a dataset
The standard deviation of a dataset
questions.explanation: A p-value is the probability of obtaining results as extreme as the observed results, assuming the null hypothesis is true. It helps determine statistical significance.
